docs.title: Welcome to Komandorr
docs.text: Modern Service Monitoring Dashboard

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Komandorr is a powerful, feature-rich service monitoring dashboard designed to keep track of your applications, websites, APIs, panels, and infrastructure. With SQLite-backed data persistence, built-in Plex integration, traffic monitoring, and 11 beautiful themes, Komandorr makes monitoring your services simple, elegant, and scalable.

Version 1.7.0 brings major UI improvements with 4-column grid layouts, compact service cards, problem badges, clickable stats navigation, and updated navigation labels.

docs.title: Real-Time Service Monitoring
docs.text: Monitor unlimited services in real-time with customizable health checks, service grouping, and instant status visibility. Set individual check intervals from 30 seconds to 1 hour per service.

docs.title: SQLite Database Storage
docs.text: Efficient database backend stores up to 1000 historical data points per service. Automatic migration from JSON, better performance, and reliable data persistence.

docs.title: VOD Streams (Plex Integration)
docs.text: Seamlessly integrate with Plex Media Server to monitor and display your video-on-demand streams with real-time playback information.

docs.title: Traffic & Bandwidth Monitoring
docs.text: Track bandwidth usage and network traffic with beautiful visualizations, response time graphs, and comprehensive historical data.

docs.title: 11 Beautiful Themes
docs.text: Choose from 11 stunning themes: Dark, Plex, Jellyfin, Emby, Seerr, and 6 Marvel Infinity Stone-inspired themes.

docs.title: Multi-Language Support
docs.text: Fully localized interface with English and German support (more languages coming soon).

docs.title: Optional Authentication
docs.text: Built-in username/password protection with session management to secure your dashboard.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Get started with Komandorr in minutes:

Git CloneDockerDocker Compose 
# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/cyb3rgh05t/komandorr.git
cd komandorr

# Run setup (Windows)
.\setup.ps1

# Start backend
cd backend && python run.py

# Start frontend (new terminal)
cd frontend && npm run dev

docker run -d \
  --name komandorr \
  -p 8000:8000 \
  -p 3000:3000 \
  -v $(pwd)/data:/app/backend/data \
  cyb3rgh05t/komandorr:latest

version: '3.8'
services:
  komandorr:
    image: cyb3rgh05t/komandorr:latest
    ports:
      - "8000:8000"  # Backend API
      - "3000:3000"  # Frontend UI
    volumes:
      - ./data:/app/backend/data
    environment:
      - ENABLE_AUTH=false
      - TIMEZONE=Europe/Berlin

Visit Getting Started for detailed installation instructions.

docs.title: Why Komandorr?
docs.text:
• Easy to Use: Simple configuration with environment variables and intuitive web interface
  • Beautiful UI: Modern, responsive interface built with React and Tailwind CSS, inspired by Sonarr/Radarr
  • Flexible: Support for various service types, custom check intervals, and service grouping
  • Scalable: SQLite database stores up to 1000 historical points per service
  • Extensible: Full REST API with OpenAPI documentation for integration
  • Lightweight: Minimal resource usage with efficient monitoring and automatic cleanup
  • Customizable: 11 themes, multi-language support, and optional authentication
  • Self-Hosted: Complete control over your monitoring data

docs.title: Technology Stack
docs.text:
• Backend: Python 3.10+ with FastAPI and SQLAlchemy ORM
  • Frontend: React 18 with Vite, TailwindCSS, and Lucide Icons
  • Database: SQLite 3 for lightweight, serverless data storage
  • API: RESTful API with automatic OpenAPI/Swagger documentation

docs.text:

docs.text: !!! warning "Protect Sensitive Data" - Never commit tokens or passwords to git - Use environment variables for secrets - Restrict file permissions: chmod 600 config.json - Rotate credentials regularly - Use strong passwords

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Configure Komandorr using environment variables for Docker deployments and system-level settings.

docs.title: ADMIN_PASSWORD
docs.text:
Admin account password.

  • Required: Yes
  • Default: admin
  • Example: ADMIN_PASSWORD=SecureP@ssw0rd!

Change Default Password

Always change the default password in production!

docs.title: CHECK_INTERVAL
docs.text:
Global service check interval in seconds.

  • Required: No
  • Default: 60
  • Range: 30-3600
  • Example: CHECK_INTERVAL=120

docs.title: LOG_LEVEL
docs.text:
Logging verbosity level.

  • Required: No
  • Default: INFO
  • Options: DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR
  • Example: LOG_LEVEL=DEBUG

docs.title: PLEX_URL
docs.text:
Plex Media Server URL.

  • Required: No (required for VOD features)
  • Format: http://hostname:port
  • Example: PLEX_URL=http://192.168.1.100:32400

docs.title: PLEX_TOKEN
docs.text:
Plex authentication token.

  • Required: No (required with PLEX_URL)
  • Example: PLEX_TOKEN=zxcvbnmasdfghjkl1234567890

How to get Plex token →

docs.title: TRAFFIC_ENABLED
docs.text:
Enable traffic monitoring feature.

  • Required: No
  • Default: false
  • Example: TRAFFIC_ENABLED=true

docs.title: TRAFFIC_INTERFACE
docs.text:
Network interface to monitor.

  • Required: No
  • Default: eth0
  • Example: TRAFFIC_INTERFACE=eno1

docs.title: DATABASE_PATH
docs.text:
SQLite database file path.

  • Required: No
  • Default: data/komandorr.db
  • Example: DATABASE_PATH=/app/data/komandorr.db

docs.title: HOST
docs.text:
Server bind address.

  • Required: No
  • Default: 0.0.0.0
  • Example: HOST=127.0.0.1

docs.title: PORT
docs.text:
Server port.

  • Required: No
  • Default: 3000
  • Example: PORT=8080

docs.title: CORS_ORIGINS
docs.text:
Allowed CORS origins (comma-separated).

  • Required: No
  • Default: *
  • Example: CORS_ORIGINS=http://localhost:3000,https://komandorr.example.com

docs.title: Docker Run
docs.text:
docker run -d \
  --name komandorr \
  -p 3000:3000 \
  -v $(pwd)/data:/app/data \
  -e ADMIN_PASSWORD=SecurePassword123 \
  -e CHECK_INTERVAL=60 \
  -e LOG_LEVEL=INFO \
  -e PLEX_URL=http://192.168.1.100:32400 \
  -e PLEX_TOKEN=your-plex-token \
  -e TRAFFIC_ENABLED=true \
  -e TRAFFIC_INTERFACE=eth0 \
  cyb3rgh05t/komandorr:latest

docs.title: Docker Compose
docs.text:
version: "3.8"

services:
  komandorr:
    image: cyb3rgh05t/komandorr:latest
    container_name: komandorr
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    volumes:
      - ./data:/app/data
    environment:
      # General
      - ADMIN_PASSWORD=SecurePassword123
      - CHECK_INTERVAL=60
      - LOG_LEVEL=INFO

      # Plex
      - PLEX_URL=http://plex-server:32400
      - PLEX_TOKEN=your-plex-token

      # Traffic
      - TRAFFIC_ENABLED=true
      - TRAFFIC_INTERFACE=eth0

      # Server
      - HOST=0.0.0.0
      - PORT=3000
    restart: unless-stopped

docs.title: .env File
docs.text:
Create a .env file for easier management:

# General Settings
ADMIN_PASSWORD=SecurePassword123
CHECK_INTERVAL=60
LOG_LEVEL=INFO

# Plex Integration
PLEX_URL=http://192.168.1.100:32400
PLEX_TOKEN=your-plex-token-here

# Traffic Monitoring
TRAFFIC_ENABLED=true
TRAFFIC_INTERFACE=eth0

# Database
DATABASE_PATH=/app/data/komandorr.db

# Server
HOST=0.0.0.0
PORT=3000
CORS_ORIGINS=*

Use with Docker Compose:

version: "3.8"

services:
  komandorr:
    image: cyb3rgh05t/komandorr:latest
    env_file:
      - .env
    ports:
      - "${PORT}:${PORT}"
    volumes:
      - ./data:/app/data

docs.title: Environment Priority
docs.text:
Configuration loading order (highest priority first):

  1. Environment Variables
  2. Configuration File (config.json)
  3. Default Values

docs.title: Security Best Practices
docs.text: !!! warning "Sensitive Data" - Never commit .env files to version control - Add .env to .gitignore - Use secrets management in production - Rotate credentials regularly - Use strong passwords (12+ characters)

docs.title: Validation
docs.text:
Komandorr validates environment variables on startup:

  • Type checking (string, number, boolean)
  • Range validation (min/max values)
  • Format validation (URLs, tokens)
  • Required field checking

Errors are logged on startup if validation fails.

docs.title: Traffic Monitoring
docs.text: Monitor network bandwidth usage with real-time and historical data visualization.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Komandorr's traffic monitoring feature tracks network bandwidth consumption, providing insights into upload/download usage patterns.

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
Traffic monitoring consists of two components:

  1. Traffic Agent - Runs on monitored servers
  2. Komandorr Dashboard - Displays and stores metrics

docs.title: Install Traffic Agent
docs.text:
On the server you want to monitor:

# Clone repository or download traffic agent
git clone https://github.com/cyb3rgh05t/komandorr.git
cd komandorr/traffic

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Run the agent
python traffic_agent.py

docs.title: Configure Agent
docs.text:
Edit traffic_agent.py or set environment variables:

export KOMANDORR_URL=http://your-komandorr:3000
export INTERFACE=eth0
export INTERVAL=5

Or modify the script:

KOMANDORR_URL = "http://your-komandorr:3000"
INTERFACE = "eth0"  # Network interface to monitor
INTERVAL = 5        # Update interval in seconds

docs.title: Network Interfaces
docs.text:
Identify your network interface:

LinuxWindowsmacOS 
ip link show
# or
ifconfig

ipconfig
# or
Get-NetAdapter

ifconfig
# or
networksetup -listallhardwareports

Common interfaces:

  • eth0 - Primary ethernet (Linux)
  • eno1 - Ethernet (Linux, systemd naming)
  • wlan0 - WiFi (Linux)
  • en0 - Primary network (macOS)

docs.title: Bandwidth Usage
docs.text:
• Upload Rate - Current bytes/sec uploaded
  • Download Rate - Current bytes/sec downloaded
  • Total Upload - Cumulative bytes uploaded
  • Total Download - Cumulative bytes downloaded

docs.title: Visualizations
docs.text:
• Real-time line charts
  • Historical data (last 24 hours)
  • Peak usage indicators
  • Average bandwidth calculations

docs.title: Real-time Monitoring
docs.text:
View current traffic in real-time:

  • Live upload/download rates
  • Color-coded graphs
  • Auto-refreshing display

docs.title: Historical Data
docs.text:
Analyze traffic patterns:

  • Last hour, day, week, or month
  • Identify peak usage times
  • Compare trends over time

docs.title: Data Retention
docs.text:
• In-memory: Last 100 data points
  • Database: Last 1000 data points per service
  • Automatic cleanup of old data

docs.title: Update Interval
docs.text:
Configure how often traffic data is collected:

INTERVAL = 5  # Update every 5 seconds

Recommended values:

  • Real-time monitoring: 5-10 seconds
  • General monitoring: 30-60 seconds
  • Light monitoring: 300+ seconds

docs.title: API Endpoint
docs.text:
Point the agent to your Komandorr instance:

KOMANDORR_URL = "http://localhost:3000"

docs.title: Linux (systemd)
docs.text:
Create /etc/systemd/system/komandorr-traffic.service:

[Unit]
Description=Komandorr Traffic Agent
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
User=komandorr
WorkingDirectory=/opt/komandorr/traffic
ExecStart=/usr/bin/python3 traffic_agent.py
Restart=always
Environment="KOMANDORR_URL=http://your-komandorr:3000"
Environment="INTERFACE=eth0"

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

Enable and start:

sudo systemctl enable komandorr-traffic
sudo systemctl start komandorr-traffic
sudo systemctl status komandorr-traffic

docs.title: Docker
docs.text:
Run the traffic agent in a container:

docker run -d \
  --name traffic-agent \
  --network host \
  -e KOMANDORR_URL=http://your-komandorr:3000 \
  -e INTERFACE=eth0 \
  cyb3rgh05t/komandorr-traffic:latest

Network Mode

The --network host flag is required for the agent to access network interfaces.

docs.title: Agent Not Connecting
docs.text:
Connection refused

Check:

- Komandorr URL is correct
- Komandorr is running and accessible
- No firewall blocking connection
- Network connectivity

docs.title: No Data Appearing
docs.text:
No traffic data

Verify:

- Correct network interface name
- Interface is active: `ip link show <interface>`
- Agent has permissions to read interface stats
- Agent is actually sending data (check logs)

docs.title: Permission Errors
docs.text:
Permission denied reading interface

Linux Solution:

Run with sudo or give capabilities:
```bash
sudo setcap cap_net_raw,cap_net_admin=eip /usr/bin/python3
```

docs.title: API Access
docs.text:
Get traffic data via API:

# Get current traffic
curl http://localhost:3000/api/traffic/current

# Get historical data
curl http://localhost:3000/api/traffic/history?hours=24

See Traffic API Reference for full documentation.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Choose Correct Interface: Monitor the interface with internet traffic
  2. Appropriate Interval: Balance data granularity with performance
  3. Run as Service: Ensure agent starts on boot
  4. Monitor Resources: Traffic agent uses minimal CPU/memory
  5. Secure Connection: Use HTTPS for agent-to-Komandorr communication

docs.title: VOD Streams (Plex Integration)
docs.text: Monitor and display your Plex Media Server video-on-demand streams directly in Komandorr.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The VOD Streams feature integrates seamlessly with Plex Media Server to provide insights into your media library and active streams.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Plex Media Server installed and running
  • Plex authentication token
  • Network access to Plex server from Komandorr

docs.title: 1. Get Your Plex Token
docs.text:
Find your Plex authentication token:

  1. Open a media item in Plex Web App
  2. Click Get Info (ℹ️ icon)
  3. Click View XML
  4. Look for X-Plex-Token in the URL

Or follow Plex's official guide.

docs.title: 2. Configure Komandorr
3. Verify Connection
docs.text:
After configuration:

  1. Go to VOD Streams page
  2. If configured correctly, you'll see your Plex library information
  3. Active streams will appear in real-time

docs.title: Library Overview
docs.text:
View your Plex library statistics:

  • Total movies
  • Total TV shows
  • Total episodes
  • Total music tracks

docs.title: Active Streams
docs.text:
Monitor currently playing content:

  • Media Title - What's being watched
  • User - Who's watching
  • Player - Device/app being used
  • Progress - Playback position

docs.title: Connection Failed
docs.text:
Cannot connect to Plex

Causes:

- Incorrect URL or port
- Invalid authentication token
- Network connectivity issues
- Firewall blocking access

**Solutions:**

- Verify Plex server is running
- Check URL includes `http://` or `https://`
- Confirm port is 32400 (default)
- Test connection from Komandorr server: `curl http://plex-server:32400`

docs.title: No Streams Showing
docs.text: !!! warning "Streams not appearing" - Ensure something is actually playing - Check Plex server has playback activity - Refresh the VOD Streams page - Verify token has necessary permissions

docs.title: Authentication Errors
docs.text: !!! error "Authentication failed" - Generate a new Plex token - Ensure token hasn't expired - Check token is copied completely - Verify Plex account has server access

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text: !!! warning "Security Best Practices" - Never expose your Plex token publicly - Use HTTPS for Plex connections when possible - Restrict network access to Plex server - Regularly rotate authentication tokens - Use Plex's built-in user permissions

docs.title: API Access
docs.text:
Access VOD stream data programmatically:

curl http://localhost:3000/api/plex/streams

See Plex API Reference for full documentation.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Configure Komandorr to monitor your services and integrate with your infrastructure.

docs.title: Configuration Methods
docs.text:
Komandorr can be configured using:

  1. Environment Variables - For Docker deployments
  2. Configuration Files - For manual installations
  3. Web Interface - Runtime configuration through the UI

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Set these environment variables in your Docker deployment:

Variable Description Default Required PLEX_URL Plex server URL - No PLEX_TOKEN Plex authentication token - No CHECK_INTERVAL Service check interval (seconds) 60 No LOG_LEVEL Logging level (DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR) INFO No ADMIN_PASSWORD Admin password admin Yes

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
Create backend/data/config.json:

{
  "check_interval": 60,
  "plex": {
    "url": "http://your-plex-server:32400",
    "token": "your-plex-token"
  },
  "traffic": {
    "enabled": true,
    "interface": "eth0"
  }
}

docs.title: Service Configuration
docs.text:
Services are configured through the web interface or by editing backend/data/services.json:

{
  "services": [
    {
      "name": "My Website",
      "url": "https://example.com",
      "type": "website",
      "group": "Production",
      "interval": 60,
      "enabled": true
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: Service Properties
docs.text:
• name: Display name for the service
  • url: URL to monitor (HTTP/HTTPS)
  • type: Service type (website, app, panel, server)
  • group: Organization group
  • interval: Check interval in seconds (overrides global)
  • enabled: Enable/disable monitoring

docs.text:

  • Services Configuration

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Learn how to install Komandorr using your preferred method.

docs.title: Docker Installation
docs.text:
Recommended Method

Docker is the recommended installation method for most users.

docs.title: Using Docker Run
docs.text:
docker run -d \
  --name komandorr \
  -p 3000:3000 \
  -v $(pwd)/data:/app/data \
  -e PLEX_URL=http://your-plex-server:32400 \
  -e PLEX_TOKEN=your-plex-token \
  cyb3rgh05t/komandorr:latest

docs.title: Using Docker Compose
docs.text:
Create a docker-compose.yml file:

version: "3.8"

services:
  komandorr:
    image: cyb3rgh05t/komandorr:latest
    container_name: komandorr
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    volumes:
      - ./data:/app/data
    environment:
      - PLEX_URL=http://your-plex-server:32400
      - PLEX_TOKEN=your-plex-token
      - CHECK_INTERVAL=60
    restart: unless-stopped

Start the container:

docker-compose up -d

docs.title: Backend Setup
docs.text:
1. Clone the repository:
git clone https://github.com/cyb3rgh05t/komandorr.git
cd komandorr
  1. Install Python dependencies:
cd backend
pip install -r requirements.txt
  1. Start the backend:
python run.py

docs.title: Frontend Setup
docs.text:
1. Install Node.js dependencies:
cd frontend
npm install
  1. Build the frontend:
npm run build
  1. Start the development server:
npm run dev

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
After installation, verify Komandorr is running:

  1. Open your browser to http://localhost:3000
  2. You should see the Komandorr login screen
  3. Default credentials: admin / admin (change immediately!)
